theJudgeTextsList.author: –ê–≤—Ç–æ—Ä: Mitchell Wintrow
theJudgeTextsList.chapter_2_content: ‚ÄúRay, is everything okay?‚Äù Raymond‚Äôs wife Siloah asked him with a concerned look on her face as she sat down on the couch next to him. He let out a long sigh as he stared vacantly into space, swirling his glass of whiskey and making the ice clink against the sides of the glass. ‚ÄúYeah, everything is okay Sil, thank you for always being so good. I‚Äôm just a bit stressed about this murder case I have to preside over tomorrow. I‚Äôve never worked a case with this much publicity before, nor with this magnitude of charges‚Äù, he responded, snapping out of his vacant stare and looking into Sil‚Äôs eyes with gratitude and love. ‚ÄúWell, I think it‚Äôs completely reasonable to feel a bit stressed or nervous before a case like this, but you know what? I‚Äôve known you to judge hundreds of cases before this, and clearly you have the ability to do this. You‚Äôll be fine. I love you and I support you completely, Ray, just remember this okay?‚Äù, she said as she leaned forward to hug Ray and put her head on his shoulder. He lifted his chin slightly and turned to lean his head over onto hers. `Hah, it‚Äôs not the ability to judge this case that I‚Äôm worried about`, he thought. In that moment he wished more than anything that he could share his deepest secret, but despite this urge to share it with his most beloved friend and partner, his wife, something even deeper within him nagged and pushed him away from divulging it to her. He kissed her head and said, ‚ÄúI love you Sil, you‚Äôre the most amazing woman I know. Maybe you‚Äôre right, I‚Äôve come this far already and I intend to keep going. As long as I have you, I‚Äôll be alright.‚Äù Ray took two large swigs from his glass of whiskey, and fought back the stress eating away at him. The next morning he woke up to his alarm blaring repeatedly, and unfortunately, he also woke up to a pounding headache. ‚ÄúAghhh‚Äù, he grunted as he reached for his phone to shut the alarm off. `What a wonderful way to start the morning of my big case`, Ray thought sarcastically as he sat up and placed his feet into his slippers next to the bed. He rubbed his eyes and massaged his temples while thinking `Good grief, my head is really killing me right now. I didn‚Äôt even drink that much whiskey last night, just one glass. Must‚Äôve been dehydrated too I guess.` He walked into the kitchen and drank a full glass of water, then refilled it again and took some Paracetamol to relieve the pain. ‚ÄúGood morning Silly‚Äù, Ray playfully joked with Sil as he walked up and kissed her in the kitchen. She chuckled and kissed him back, replying ‚ÄúGood morning old man‚Äù with a smirk as she flipped over the eggs frying in the pan. ‚ÄúWhoa, whoa, who are you calling old?‚Äù he retorted, laughing and already beginning to feel better. ‚ÄúThanks for the breakfast dear, you are the best. I didn‚Äôt even hear you get up this morning‚Äù, Ray said as he sat down at the kitchen table. ‚ÄúWho says this breakfast is for you?‚Äù, Sil said tauntingly with a smile, turning to look at Ray. He met her gaze, raised one eyebrow, then began smiling as they both started laughing. A few moments later she brought over a plate of eggs, hash browns, and bacon with a glass of orange juice and set it in front of him. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to do great today Ray, I believe in you. Enjoy your breakfast and drink your orange juice, it should make your head feel better and then you‚Äôll be ready to go.‚Äù ‚ÄúThank you, Sil. Have I ever told you that you‚Äôre the best? Because you are‚Äù he said as he took a big bite of food. ‚ÄúLove you‚Äù he said in a muffled voice with a mouth full of food. Sil laughed and kissed his forehead, ‚ÄúLove you too‚Äù. Judge Elisando‚Äôs office before court begins‚Ä¶ Raymond sat behind the big oak desk in his office, with the early morning light shining in from the window behind him and casting light onto the pile of documents he was reading. With his thumb massaging his right temple and his fingers on his forehead, he sighed and continued reading the document held in his left hand in front of him. Not only was his head still bothering him, but this case was turning out to be a bigger deal than he initially realized. Originally, he was under the impression that this was a murder investigation with some strange circumstances, but now it‚Äôs come to light that this defendant isn‚Äôt just some random person. The defendant is Quinton Franks, son of the wealthy and famous politician and business owner, Mason Franks. At a young age Mason had immigrated here with his parents, who then started a real estate business and quickly became wealthy. As he grew up, Mason loved going with his father to view the different real estate properties that were being bought and sold. This ended up providing him with many opportunities to meet other wealthy and famous people interested in the properties, including many different politicians and government officials, inspiring Mason to pursue a career in politics. Given that Mason, even from a young age when first meeting all of these officials, left a memorable impression on them as a clever and charming young man, it came as no surprise to the community when he ended up being elected as a State senator. Shortly after Mason‚Äôs election, however, his father passed away and left the family real estate business to him. Many people worried about what would happen to either the business or Mason, thinking that there was no way he could handle both, but these worries were soon quashed when he married Cheryl Binds. Cheryl Binds, now Cheryl Franks, came from another family owned real estate business and knew exactly how to keep the business alive. Not only did she keep the business alive, but she expanded the business and began contracting towers to be built in major cities like New York, Seattle, and San Francisco, which propelled the family wealth into the top 10% of the country. About a year after the third tower was built, Mason and Cheryl had their son Quinton. Quinton had every opportunity to excel in life. He went to prestigious schools, met many famous politicians, business owners, and actors, who were all charmed by him, just like his father Mason. The difference with Quinton, however, is that he had a tendency to deal with some of the shadier characters in the world of business and politics. There had been at least a couple of occasions in the news where Quinton had been accused by whistleblowers for using his connections and power to influence business purchases and elections of officials that he supported, yet these officials did not seem to have the community support one would expect to see for an official that had supposedly been elected by the community. But as many of these accusations against high ranking people go, they were thrown out as hearsay and charges were dropped. The accusations did leave their mark on his reputation though, and the community had their growing suspicions and doubt of his trustworthiness. This information reeled in Raymond‚Äôs mind, making his head begin to pound again. He reached for the glass of water to his right and drank the entire glass, crunching and chewing the remaining ice as he continued to read the details of the murder Quinton was being accused of. Raymond‚Äôs eyes fervently scanned line after line of text, absorbing and digesting the information, fighting off any prejudices attempting to work their way into his mind. In the affidavit, Quinton is being accused of masterminding a plot to ‚Äútake care of‚Äù a problematic realtor, Mr. Jefferson, who leaked information about a scheme to launder money by purchasing property from a shady politician. Mr. Jefferson leaked documents that proved this transaction was not only money laundering, but also bribery, because Quinton actually already owned this property and essentially paid this politician as a bribe, using the purchase of property from the politician as a way to launder the money by making it look like the politician owned the property. When Mr. Jefferson failed to come home after work, his family called the police to report him missing, because they were already aware that he had leaked this information to a reporter and were worried something may have happened to him. Later it was discovered that the day Mr. Jefferson failed to come home after work, he had been showing a new property to Quinton in a remote area. Police found CCTV footage of Quinton and Mr. Jefferson driving together in the same vehicle on the way to the property, but on the way back only Quinton could be seen in the vehicle. Later, Mr. Jefferson‚Äôs family was told by an associate of his that he expressed worry over showing this property to Quinton alone, and then his family presented this information to police. Eventually when police found that Mr. Jefferson had ‚Äúfallen‚Äù from a cliff, and they put together the suspicious evidence, the murder charges were made against Quinton. Despite how suspicious all of the events surrounding the case seemed and how they seemed to be pointing directly at Quinton as the prime suspect, the prosecution was hard pressed to find any other evidence to directly tie him to the crime. At the scene there was no evidence of a struggle, in the CCTV footage Mr. Jefferson did not seem to be distressed while driving on the way out there, examining both Quinton‚Äôs and Mr. Jefferson‚Äôs phones yielded no incriminating or even remotely suspicious text messages, and furthermore, Quinton clearly and obviously hired the best lawyer he could afford, and he could afford more than most people in the country. Still, there was motive based on Mr. Jefferson leaking the information, Quinton was seen leaving without Mr. Jefferson after viewing the remote property, and the claims from the family and work associate about his worry to show this property to Quinton alone. ‚ÄúWhat am I getting myself into?‚Äù Raymond sighed to himself, setting the documents down and leaning back in his chair. He reached for his glass of water and rubbed his temples again, but realized the glass was empty. Walking over to the pitcher to pour some more water, Raymond mentally flipped through all of the potential ways this case could play out. In the courtroom, the case is beginning‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúAll rise‚Äù, said the bailiff as Judge Elisando entered the courtroom from the door behind his raised desk, and approached his seat. Immediately the murmuring of the court began to quiet down, and clicks and flashes could be heard and seen as the reporters tried to get the best angles before court was in session. ‚ÄúThank you, you may be seated‚Äù, Ray said as he too sat down at his raised desk. ‚ÄúNow, let‚Äôs set the record showing that this is just the preliminary hearing. After the prosecution has proclaimed the charges against the defendant and their merit for making these claims based on whatever evidence may be presented, the defense will have a chance to refute any accusations made by the prosecution and the defendant will plead either guilty or not guilty. From that point, I will make the judgment on how this case will proceed. Are we in agreement with these proceedings?‚Äù ‚ÄúYes, your honor‚Äù, both the prosecution and defense responded simultaneously. ‚ÄúGood, then Mr. Thompson please proceed‚Äù, Raymond instructed. Mr. Eddie Thompson, the prosecution, thanked him as he stood up and straightened his tie. Walking toward the bench where Judge Elisando sat listening intently, Eddie began to disseminate all of the facts to the courtroom that Ray had previously been reading about in his office. When Ray happened to look at the defendant, Quinton, however, he noticed something strange with his aura. Looking directly at Quinton, he could only see a constant bright white aura of ultra high definition being emanated, but as Ray turned to continue looking at Eddie as he laid out the charges and evidence, he noticed a faint distortion and shimmering out of the corner of his eye. To confirm his suspicions, Ray continued to look at Eddie, but his focus was on the corner of his eye where Quinton was sitting. Sure enough, there it is. That same guilty shimmering distortion was definitely there. But how could this be? Ray had never seen anything like this before. Previously, it was always abundantly clear whether or not the defendant was guilty, but this time, it was almost as if Quinton was purposefully ‚Äúwearing‚Äù an innocent aura despite his guilty shimmering aura being emanated underneath his peculiar form of ‚Äúclothing‚Äù. `Truly, what am I getting myself into?``, Raymond thought to himself, feeling a bit worried now about how this case will turn out. Again, he focused on the corner of his eye where Quinton was calmly seated, not moving a muscle or displaying any kind of emotion whatsoever. Sure enough, that distorted shimmer was there. Raymond subconsciously began massaging his temple with his left hand, as that deep pain started to manifest behind his eyes again. `Man, maybe I need to look into a new prescription again. These glasses seem to work just fine, but focusing on the corner of my vision like that is not making my head feel happy, that‚Äôs for sure.`, he thought, continuing to rub his left temple. Finally, Eddie had finished presenting his charges and the evidence to support them, and the defense, Mr. Victor Broughton, stood up to begin his representation of the defendant. As Victor presented his defense, however, Ray was having trouble listening, because all he could seem to think about was how strange Quinton‚Äôs aura was. What finally ended up snapping Ray back to attention in the present moment was the defendant, Quinton, pleading ‚Äúnot guilty‚Äù. Now he knew it was his turn to carry on the show, and said ‚ÄúOnce the court has selected jurors for the trial, we will reconvene and both sides will have their opportunity to present the evidence and defense in depth to the jurors.‚Äù Ray stood up to leave back to his office and the bailiff once again said ‚ÄúAll rise‚Äù as he walked and opened the door to his office. Closing the door behind him, Ray let out a deep sigh and began massaging both of his temples, wincing at the pain behind his eyes. He walked back over to his office chair and took several swigs of the barely cool water left in his glass covered in condensation from the melted ice. Once the glass was empty, he inadvertently set the glass down forcefully which ended up shattering all over his desk and onto the floor. ‚ÄúDamnit‚Äù, he said to himself. That‚Äôs when the unsettling thought occurred to him, what if this is an omen or a symbol of how this case will end up? But if it is, who‚Äôs the one that will end up shattered and in pieces, him or Quinton? Ray swallowed dryly and thought, `I hope not me`, but his gut was telling him something different‚Ä¶
